publicationStmt.p: This project encoded newspaper and periodical articles on ghost hoaxes in the Victorian period. This publication of the text serves as data in a collaborative laboratory edition for the 2022 NEH Institute "Advanced digital editing: modeling the text and making the edition" at the University of Pittsburgh.

seriesStmt.title: Ghost hoaxes in 19th-century British news media

sourceDesc.p: All texts in this collection were sourced from British periodical and newspaper archives, transcribed,and encoded. The citation below was provided by the archive and appears exactly as given.

p.bibl: "A Ghost." Weekly Times, 9 Oct. 1836. Nineteenth Century Collections Online, tinyurl.galegroup.com/tinyurl/54S2x9. Accessed 25 July 2017.

projectDesc.p: This document is part of a larger digital collection of stories of ghost hoaxes from the 18th and 19th century London newspapers and periodicals. The project explores the beginnings of mass print media in a metropolitan area at a time when technology and education made reading increasingly common and inexpensive.

The corpus holds 36 individual documents, which reflect a diverse mix of reporting on various hauntings in and around London between 1804 and 1889. The PDF and JPEGs from online databases were transcribed using ABBYFineReader OCR, then corrected and occasionally manually transcribed if document quality necessitated it. After normalization in plain text, all documents were upconverted to TEI XML.

normalization.p: Earlier texts have had some spelling normalization due to errors in OCR. Typographic em dashes are longer than modern em dashes, so all dashes have been normalized to modern em dash length.

quotation.p: All extraneous white space used by printers to avoid overlapping with letters has been removed. All quotes are simply tagged with the q tag.

body.p: The inhabitants of the lonely portion of Pentonville, beyond Maiden-lane, called the French Colony, have for some weeks past been in a state of considerable excitement and alarm, in consequence of the reports of a ghost of collossal form, habited in the regular spectral costume of a white sheet, with a black mask on his face, having been seen stalking about the fields and lanes by several persons, to whom his formidable appearance gave great alarm; indeed, one of the ghost seers, a little girl about thirteen years of age, was so excessively frightened as to have been ever since entirely bereft of speech and reason. The police were apprised of the circumstance, and made several endeavours to apprehend him, but apprised by some means of their solicitude, he kept aloof for some nights. On the Wednesday evening of last week, however, as two men were returning across the fields from Copenhagen House, they espied a tall figure start up from behind a cow, where it evidently had been couchant, and advance with rapid strides towards them, uttering the most awful groans. The men, however, had heard of his ghostship before, and waited his approach sans peur, till he got within range of their sticks, when they knocked him down, and continued belaboring him most unmercifully, till his screams convinced them it was flesh and blood upon which they were so vigorously exercising the argumentum baculinum, and brought the police to the spot. He was immediately carried to the station-house, where it was discovered, from his severe castigation, he had three ribs broken, besides the other parts of his corporeal person being terribly battered and bruised. The next morning he was taken before Mr. Laing, at Hatton-garden Police-office, and by that magistrate sentenced to three monthsâ€™ imprisonment in the House of Correction, which it is to be hoped will operate as a warning to him and to others not to play tricks of so injurious a tendency in future.
